title: 115_s2031
content: The "Kisatchie National Forest Land Conveyance Act" authorizes the conveyance of certain Federal land in the Kisatchie National Forest in Louisiana for market value consideration. The Act defines terms such as "Collins Camp Properties," "Secretary," and "State." The "Kisatchie National Forest Land Conveyance Act" allows the Secretary to convey Federal land in Louisiana by quitclaim deed for public or private sale. The land includes specified parcels in Winn Parish. During a 1-year period, there is a first right of purchase for interested parties. The "Kisatchie National Forest Land Conveyance Act" allows the Secretary to convey Federal land in Louisiana by quitclaim deed for public or private sale. This includes parcels in Winn Parish, with a first right of purchase for interested parties within a 1-year period. The Secretary has the authority to convey Federal land in Louisiana under the "Kisatchie National Forest Land Conveyance Act." The conveyance may include parcels in Winn Parish and the terms and conditions, as well as consideration for the conveyance, are determined by the Secretary. The conveyance of Federal land under the "Kisatchie National Forest Land Conveyance Act" requires consideration in the form of cash equal to the market value of the land, determined by an appraisal or competitive sale. In any conveyance of Federal land under this Act, the Secretary must disclose hazardous substances but is not required to remediate them. The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 still applies to the conveyances of Federal land. SEC. 5. PROCEEDS FROM THE SALE OF LAND. The Secretary will deposit proceeds from the sale of Federal land under section 4 into the fund established under the Sisk Act. SEC. 6. ADMINISTRATION. Collins Camp Properties must pay appraisal and administrative costs for the conveyance of Federal land. They also need written statements from holders of Forest Service special use authorizations agreeing to relinquish them upon acquisition of the land. Collins Camp Properties must pay appraisal and administrative costs for the conveyance of Federal land. If holders of special use authorizations fail to provide written authorization, Collins Camp Properties must administer the authorization until it expires.
